misc.text: ğŸ§¡Lost in Translation: For this chapter title, Oda deliberately chose wording that sounds like a line from a fairy tale, fitting for the Elbaf arc, which makes it difficult to translate. If it were up to me, I'd render it like this: ğŸ—ï¸The very strongest thing in all the world. misc.title: #ONEPIECE1174 Well, the only kanji in the WSJ title version is â€œ1ç•ªâ€ (ichiban â€“ â€œnumber oneâ€), and now the official version says itâ€™s supposed to be written in pure hiraganaâ€”â€œã„ã¡ã°ã‚“.â€ This makes it much
misc.text: #ONEPIECE1174 Well, the only kanji in the WSJ title version is â€œ1ç•ªâ€ (ichiban â€“ â€œnumber oneâ€), and now the official version says itâ€™s supposed to be written in pure hiraganaâ€”â€œã„ã¡ã°ã‚“.â€ This makes it much simpler, as if it were written from a childâ€™s perspective. In my initial explanation, I focused on the â€œmonoâ€ (ã‚‚ã®) part of the chapter title because it was written in hiragana instead of kanji. In Japanese, â€œmonoâ€ can be written using two different kanji: â€œç‰©â€ (for non-living things) and â€œè€…â€ (for a person). I think it was intended that way to make the meaning ambiguous (and I still think it is, in my opinion)â€”whether it refers to parental love as the â€œstrongest thing,â€ or to "the strongest person/s,â€ referring to the epic panel shown at the end of the chapter. However, when referring to the â€œstrongest person,â€ the usual descriptive term would be written in kanji as â€œæœ€å¼·â€ (saikyÅ), rather than in hiragana as â€œã„ã¡ã°ã‚“ã¤ã‚ˆã„â€ (ichiban tsuyoi). In summary, there is still no official confirmation of what the â€œstrongestâ€ refers to in this chapter, but the simplified hiragana in the chapter title makes it feel as if it were written by a child. The children witnessed both their parentsâ€™/relativesâ€™/teacher's strong and unconditional love for themâ€”and they also saw how they were saved by Luffy and Loki at the end in their strongest forms. So personally, I think the title remains open to both interpretations. items.text: #ONEPIECE1174 Well, the only kanji in the WSJ title version is â€œ1ç•ªâ€ (ichiban â€“ â€œnumber oneâ€), and now the official version says itâ€™s supposed to be written in pure hiraganaâ€”â€œã„ã¡ã°ã‚“.â€ This makes it much simpler, as if it were written from a childâ€™s perspective. In my initial explanation, I focused on the â€œmonoâ€ (ã‚‚ã®) part of the chapter title because it was written in hiragana instead of kanji. In Japanese, â€œmonoâ€ can be written using two different kanji: â€œç‰©â€ (for non-living things) and â€œè€…â€ (for a person). I think it was intended that way to make the meaning ambiguous (and I still think it is, in my opinion)â€”whether it refers to parental love as the â€œstrongest thing,â€ or to "the strongest person/s,â€ referring to the epic panel shown at the end of the chapter. However, when referring to the â€œstrongest person,â€ the usual descriptive term would be written in kanji as â€œæœ€å¼·â€ (saikyÅ), rather than in hiragana as â€œã„ã¡ã°ã‚“ã¤ã‚ˆã„â€ (ichiban tsuyoi). In summary, there is still no official confirmation of what the â€œstrongestâ€ refers to in this chapter, but the simplified hiragana in the chapter title makes it feel as if it were written by a child. The children witnessed both their parentsâ€™/relativesâ€™/teacher's strong and unconditional love for themâ€”and they also saw how they were saved by Luffy and Loki at the end in their strongest forms. So personally, I think the title remains open to both interpretations.
